description:
Bacteroides congonensis is a species of Gram-negative, anaerobic, rod-shaped bacteria that was first isolated from the human gut microbiome. It belongs to the genus Bacteroides, which is a dominant member of the phylum Bacteroidetes, commonly found in the gastrointestinal tracts of humans and other animals.

Bacteroides congonensis is a non-spore-forming, non-motile bacterium that is able to ferment various carbohydrates and produce short-chain fatty acids as metabolic end-products. It is considered an important member of the gut microbiome, playing a role in the breakdown and utilization of complex dietary polysaccharides.

The genome of Bacteroides congonensis has been sequenced, revealing insights into its metabolic capabilities, adaptations to the gut environment, and potential interactions with other members of the gut microbial community. Further research is ongoing to understand the specific ecological functions and clinical relevance of this species within the human gut microbiome.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Bacteroides congonensis
